0.user_question: Farmer Brown has 5374841 animals on his farm, all either chickens or cows. He has twice as many chickens as cows. How many legs do the animals have, all together?

1.subquestion: Let C be the number of cows; then what would you say about the number of chickens (chicken_legs)?

subanswer.text: Since there are twice as many chickens as cows, let the number of cow legs be x*C where C represents the number of cows. Then the number of chickens will be represented by y*(number of cattle) since they also contribute their own numbers of legs per animal. We know from the problem statement that Chicken Leg Count (y)*Chicken Headcount (Number of Chickens)= Total Animal Limbs count(x). ost_step.1: Let C represent the number of cows Farmer Brown owns.
ost_step.2: Accordingly, because he has twice as many chickens than cows (and since each cow has four times as many legs), we can write this equation for their combined totals: 4C+2(2C)=5374841 -> 4C+4C=5374841 -> 8C=5374841. Solving it yields that there are approximately 671855 cows on Farmer Brown’s farm; rounding down, you get exactly 671855 cows considering whole numbers only).

0.user_question: Farmer Brown has 5374841 animals on his farm, all either chickens or cows. He has twice as many chickens as cows. How many legs do the animals have, all together?

ost_step.1: Let C represent the number of cows Farmer Brown owns.
ost_step.2: Accordingly, because he has twice as many chickens than cows (and since each cow has four times as many legs), we can write this equation for their combined totals: 4C+2(2C)=5374841 -> 4C+4C=5374841 -> 8C=5374841. Solving it yields that there are approximately 671855 cows on Farmer Brown’s farm; rounding down, you get exactly 671855 cows considering whole numbers only).
